content:
I don't like this one. In my opinion, use a binary representation of a number to calculate like a decimal number is not logical. I'm sorry but I vote to refuse.

A number can have a decimal representation (eg. 13) and a binary representation (eg. 1101). This 2 representations indicate the same value: "13 on base 10" = "1101 on base 2". In my opinion, it's confusing to calculate "1101 on base 2" and to work with the number "1101 on base 10" (not the same).

But a lot of puzzles about binary conversion can be very good, like count the number of 1, the ratio of 1...

I like that one! In scripting languages with the ability to convert decimal to binary you can cheat quite a lot (as I did :P ) and as such you can quickly solve the problem. So it's perfect for a clash of code.

Good puzzle.  I've filled the stub generator before testing it.
Fun for very fast clash and golfing.
Done it with 67 char in Ruby but some here will do better I guess

Maybe, some tests with a lot of big entries would be fine to enjoy the result
